body: I would LOVE this!  Yes, please.

this would require jade to be aware of its "graph" which in some sense it is right now. But this knowledge would have to be shared with file watcher and compile logic

I have made this which generates a graph of any give jade file, so it **could** be done

https://github.com/samccone/jade-graph
@ForbesLindesay let's make this happen! who would ideal dev to implement this?

@acidjazz @ForbesLindesay I can take a stab at this... however this may be way outside of scope for core jade

I have been working on a project for a while called roots https://github.com/jenius/roots/

Which supports jade and we are currently working on implementing this very idea
https://github.com/jenius/roots/pull/187

@samccone awesome this would really help the community of projects like [cordova](http://cordova.apache.org/) where all functionality is purely front end and relying on command line tool versions of jade (and stylus) are crucial. (stylus command-line already does this BTW)

Old issue on this: https://github.com/visionmedia/jade/issues/301
I want this feature too. Watching included files and recompile works quite well in Stylus, I want that in Jade too.
you should use `grunt-contrib-watch` for this issue

https://github.com/substack/node-browserify Browserify offers a "file" event to implement file watching. In essence it will give you all the files that are required for the current "browserify" call. Quite elegant in my opinion. Jade would surely benefit from this information

rename.from: AWESOME FEATURE REQUEST: watch father file of includes

body: Grunt and browserify may work well when developing with a node project, but when using the Jade CLI for other types of projects it would be great not having to setup a project and grunt files just for this.
We now do expose the list of files that are dependencies, so this just needs implementing on the CLI.  I'm happy to take pull requests.
Thank you for reviving this @ForbesLindesay it would make my life easier to have this at the CLI :)

issue.title: Fixes for watch mode.

repository.name: pug
repository.description: Pug  robust, elegant, feature rich template engine for Node.js

issue.body:
Problems that are fixed in the request:
1. #1086
2. problem, that when watching a folder jade-cli was not watching subtrees.

Solutions provided:
1. fetch dependencies from `jade.compile`, and watch'em.
2. watch every file that is a target for render.

Improvement:
1. Unwatching a file, if the file was moved or removed.

issue.title: Rerendering dependencies does not work when child files are already watched

repository.name: pug
repository.description: Pug  robust, elegant, feature rich template engine for Node.js

issue.body:
https://github.com/jadejs/jade/issues/1086 addressed watching father files and their children jade files. It does not work for me, if the children are already being watched. Please see the example for more explanations.
# Example

A `main.jade` which includes `a.jade` and `b.jade`

```
 main.jade
 includes/
   a.jade (included from main.jade)
   b.jade (included from main.jade)
```
## working

If I watch only the `main.jade`

``` bash
jade -w *.jade
```

the files `a.jade` and `b.jade` are automatically watched (as they are a dependency from `main.jade`). If I change `a.jade`, `main.jade` will be rerendered.
## not working

If I watch all files

``` bash
jade -w .
```

all files are being watched. But if I now change `a.jade`,  only `a.jade` will be rerendered. `main.jade` will  _not_ be rerendered.

body:
@ForbesLindesay could you provide an example of accessing the list of dependencies, please? (Edit: Actually, is this how you do it? https://github.com/jadejs/brjade/issues/1)

Also, are you suggesting that jade watch doesn't recompile extended and included files, by design? For example, I have `page.jade` which extends `layout.jade`. When I made a change to `layout.jade`, `layout.html` is updated, but not `page.html`.
